quiz.question: System modeling is the process of developing abstract models of a system using only textual descriptions.
quiz.suggestion: Review the definition of system modeling, which typically uses graphical notations like UML.

quiz.question: Context models illustrate what lies outside the system boundaries.
quiz.suggestion: Recall the purpose of context models in system modeling.

quiz.question: Use case diagrams are used to model the internal structure and organization of a system.
quiz.suggestion: Remember that use case diagrams focus on interactions between a system and its environment, not internal structure.

quiz.question: Sequence diagrams show the sequence of interactions between actors and objects during a use case.
quiz.suggestion: Review the purpose and typical content of a UML sequence diagram.

quiz.question: Class diagrams are a type of behavioral model in UML.
quiz.suggestion: Class diagrams are structural models, not behavioral models.

quiz.question: Generalization in UML allows lower-level classes to inherit attributes and operations from higher-level classes.
quiz.suggestion: Recall how generalization and inheritance work in object-oriented modeling.

quiz.question: Behavioral models focus on the static organization of system components.
quiz.suggestion: Behavioral models describe dynamic behavior, not static structure.

quiz.question: Activity diagrams can be used to model data processing and business workflows.
quiz.suggestion: Review the use of activity diagrams in modeling processes.

quiz.question: State diagrams are used to model how a system responds to internal and external events.
quiz.suggestion: Recall the purpose of state diagrams in behavioral modeling.

quiz.question: Model-Driven Engineering (MDE) focuses on writing code manually as the primary development activity.
quiz.suggestion: MDE emphasizes models as the principal output, with code generated automatically.

quiz.question: A Platform-Independent Model (PIM) includes details about specific execution platforms.
quiz.suggestion: PIMs are abstract and do not include platform-specific details.

quiz.question: In UML, aggregation represents a 'part-of' relationship between classes.
quiz.suggestion: Review the meaning of aggregation in class diagrams.

quiz.question: Event-driven modeling is most suitable for data-intensive business processing systems.
quiz.suggestion: Event-driven modeling is typically used for real-time systems, not data-heavy business systems.

quiz.question: The position of a system boundary is a purely technical decision with no organizational implications.
quiz.suggestion: Recall that system boundaries can be influenced by social, organizational, and political factors.

quiz.question: Use cases can be represented both diagrammatically and in textual form.
quiz.suggestion: Review how use cases are documented in UML.

quiz.question: MDA (Model-Driven Architecture) is a code-centric approach to software development.
quiz.suggestion: MDA is a model-focused approach, not code-centric.

quiz.question: A Computation Independent Model (CIM) focuses on how the system will be implemented.
quiz.suggestion: CIMs describe the domain without considering system implementation.

quiz.question: Sequence diagrams can model interactions between system objects, not just between actors and the system.
quiz.suggestion: Recall that sequence diagrams can show object-to-object interactions internally.

quiz.question: Process models show how a system is used within broader business processes.
quiz.suggestion: Review the purpose of process models in context modeling.

quiz.question: In behavioral modeling, stimuli can only be events; data cannot trigger system processing.
quiz.suggestion: Stimuli can be either data or events in behavioral modeling.

quiz.question: MDE is widely adopted and has replaced traditional coding practices in most software organizations.
quiz.suggestion: Consider the current adoption challenges and limitations of MDE/MDA.

quiz.question: A Platform-Specific Model (PSM) is derived by adding platform details to a Platform-Independent Model.
quiz.suggestion: Review the transformation process from PIM to PSM in MDA.

quiz.question: Aggregation and generalization refer to the same type of relationship in UML class diagrams.
quiz.suggestion: Understand the difference between aggregation ('part-of') and generalization ('is-a').

quiz.question: State diagrams are only useful for modeling real-time systems and cannot be applied to business systems.
quiz.suggestion: While common in real-time systems, state diagrams can also model stateful behavior in business systems.

quiz.question: In MDE, the primary goal is to raise the level of abstraction and automatically generate code from models.
quiz.suggestion: Recall the core philosophy and benefits of Model-Driven Engineering.

quiz.question: Activity diagrams and state diagrams are both considered structural models in UML.
quiz.suggestion: Both activity and state diagrams are behavioral models, not structural.

quiz.question: The 'Transfer-data' use case example in the Mentcare system involves interaction between a patient and a doctor.
quiz.suggestion: Review the provided use case description to identify the actors involved.

quiz.question: Model-Driven Engineering is fully compatible with agile methods because both emphasize extensive upfront modeling.
quiz.suggestion: Consider the potential conflict between MDE's upfront modeling and agile's iterative, lightweight approach.

quiz.question: A structural model can be either static (showing design-time organization) or dynamic (showing runtime organization).
quiz.suggestion: Recall the two types of structural models mentioned in the chapter.

quiz.question: In UML, an association represents a link between objects of the same class only.
quiz.suggestion: Associations can exist between different classes, not just within the same class.
